t: Proverbs 25
Hezekiah’s Collection
These*pn too are proverbs of Solomon, which*ln the men of King Hezekiah of Judah copied.
It*pn is the glory of God to conceal a matter and*ln the glory of kings to investigate a matter.
As*ln the heavens are high and the earth is deep, so*ln the hearts of kings cannot be investigated.
Remove*pn impurities from silver, and*ln material will be produced for a silversmith.
Remove*ln the wicked from the king’s presence, and*ln his throne will be established in righteousness.
Don’t*pn boast about yourself before the king, and*ln don’t stand in the place of the great;
for*ln it is better for him to say to you, “Come up here!” than*ln to demote you in plain view of a noble.
Don’t*pn take a matter to court hastily. Otherwise,*ln what will you do afterward if*ln your opponent humiliates you?
Make*ln your case with your opponent without*ln revealing another’s secret;
otherwise,*ln the one who hears will disgrace you, and*ln you’ll never live it down.
A*pn word spoken at the right time is*ln like gold apples in silver settings.
A*ln wise correction to a receptive ear is*ln like a gold ring or an ornament of gold.
To*pn those who send him, a trustworthy envoy is*ln like the coolness of snow on a harvest day; he*ln refreshes the life of his masters.
The*pn one who boasts about a gift that does not exist is*ln like clouds and wind without rain.
A*ln ruler can be persuaded through patience, and*ln a gentle tongue can break a bone.
If*ln you find honey, eat only what you need; otherwise,*ln you’ll get sick from it and vomit.
Seldom*ln set foot in your neighbor’s house; otherwise,*ln he’ll get sick of you and hate you.
A*pn person giving false testimony against his neighbor is*ln like a club, a sword, or a sharp arrow.
Trusting*ln an unreliable person in a difficult time is*ln like a rotten tooth or a faltering foot.
Singing*pn songs to a troubled heart is*ln like taking off clothing on a cold day or*ln like pouring vinegar on soda.
If*pn your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat, and*ln if he is thirsty, give him water to drink,
for*ln you will heap burning coals on his head, and*ln the Lord*s will reward you.
The*pn north wind produces rain, and*ln a backbiting tongue, angry looks.
Better*pn to live on the corner of a roof than*ln to share a house with a nagging wife.
Good*pn news from a distant land is*ln like cold water to a parched throat.
A*pn righteous person who yields to the wicked is*ln like a muddied spring or a polluted well.
It*pn is not good to eat too much honey or*ln to seek glory after glory.
A*pn person who does not control his temper is*ln like a city whose wall is broken down.
